results.title: Perceptual learning
results.brief_description: This film contains three demonstrations by Dr D. C. Donderi, showing the importance of experience in determining what we see. Each demonstration illustrates a recent development in visual perception.

results.title: Perceptions
results.creator_credit: AV Unit Production and Paul White
results.brief_description: This video explains the background, motivations and dilemmas of people seeking professional counselling. It moves from the counselling session to the social context, allowing the viewer time to reflect on the psychological, social and political factors involved. For the professional helper this reflection can lead to new insights into often familiar situations. This holistic overview is an invaluable guide to those involved in analysis and intervention in a wide range of client problem areas. Areas covered include old age, racial harassment, bereavement, homosexuality, single parenthood and disability.

results.title: Perception structure or flow (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Seeing is believing, and believing is seeing, says this film, in an engaging, involving exanimation of what perception is - what causes one person to see things one way, another person in a totally different way. A film to stimulate discussion, especially in the classroom at senior levels.

results.title: Perception
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow Productions and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
This film presents the theory that perception is not merely the sensing of stimuli but is a set of elaborate processes through which we organise our sensory impressions into meaningful pictures of the objects and events around us. The basic principles that support the theory are illustrated by the activities of a group of students relaxing in a common room.

results.title: Perception
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, James McCloy and Brenda Horsfield
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Man in the Making”.
A study of the development of perception in the human being. An experiment to test the reaction of a baby to a cliff is shown. Speakers include Dr. J. M. Tanner, Dr. KM. L. Johnson Abercrombie, and Dr. Kevin Murphy.

results.title: Peppimenarti
results.creator_credit: Leopardwood, Film Australia and Ron Iddon
results.brief_description: Peppimenarti is an Aborigine owned cattle station in the Northern Territory near the Daly River. Beginning by rounding up descendants of cattle who had strayed from other stations the Aborigines have built up the station to a successful business enterprise with $1m turnover p.a. Aboriginal law takes precedence over European law, and all able-bodied men on the station must work, with none allowed to go on the dole. Peppimenarti stands as a shining example of the Aboriginal Outstation Movement, which has successfully combined western business sense with Aboriginal tribal custom.

results.title: Pepita's surprise: birthday at Patzcuaro
results.creator_credit: Visual Education Films and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: People of the picturesque region of Patzcuaro, Michoacon, Mexico as seen in their natural environment. On the occasion of a birthday excursion by Pepita and her father an intimate family fiestas is prepared for her while she is away. Musicians play the traditional birthday song “Las Mananitas” and the delighted small friends and neighbours play at breaking pinata; climax occurs when Pepita is presented with a three day old burro.

results.title: Pepi, Luci, Bom & the other girls
results.creator_credit: Pepon Corominas, Figaro Films, Pepon Coromina, Pastora Delgado, Ester Rambal and Pedro Almodovar
results.brief_description: An earlier Almodovar effort which brings to mind some of the more outrageous moments from the films of American director John Waters. Pepi, Luci and Bom’s out-to-offend plot has Pepi (Almodovar regular Carmen Maura), exact revenge on the policeman (Felix Rotaeta) who raped her by having him beaten up by her punk rock pals. When that plan backfires she hatches an even more outlandish plot which involves introducing the policeman’s mousy wife Luci (Eva Siva), to the world of sadomasochism and ‘water sports’, via her friend Bom (Olvido Gara). Of course Pepi never counted on Luci liking it so much! Unfortunately this video version is a slightly modified one from the cinema release (one of the film’s funniest moments where Bom casually urinates in Luci’s face is cut down), but Almodovar’s provocative and endearingly tasteless humour (an ad for women’s underwear that converts to a vibrator comes to mind!), still shines through.

results.title: Pepe le Moko
results.creator_credit: Robert Hakim, Raymond Hakim and Julien Duvivier
results.brief_description:
Pepe, a fugitive jewel thief lives as a gang leader in the Algerian Casbah. He is protected from justice as long as he makes no attempt to leave, but when he falls in love with a visiting Parisienne, he risks his freedom to be with her. ‘Pepe le Moko’ is the epitome of 1930s French cinema and created the myth of the doomed, romantic anti-hero. This film also served to establish Jean Gabin as a major star. A romantic, atmospheric thriller, it was crucial to the development of ‘French film noir’ and inspired a number of remakes and many imitations. Duvivier admitted that ‘Pepe’ was inspired by American ganster films, especially Howard Hawks’ ‘Scarface’. In ‘Pepe’, the gangster Max who plays the cup-and-ball is a reminder of the coin-tossing ganster played by Georges Raft in ‘Scarface’. The Algiers Casbah was fully reconstituted in studio. A few exteriors were shot on location in Sete and Marseilles. Only a few establishing shot were filmed in Algiers. ‘Pepe le Moko’ was remade in the US as ‘Algiers’ (1938) and as ‘Casbah’ (1948). Further reading: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘Pepe le Moko’. London: BFI Film Classics, 1998.

Credits: Producers, Robert and Raymond Hakim ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Pierre Ashelbe, Julien Duvivier, Henri Jeanson ; photography, Jules Kruger ; music, Vincent Scotto, Mohamed Yguerbouchen ; art direction, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Mireille Balin, Line Noro, Fernand Charpin, Saturnin Fabre, Gabriel Gabrio, Marcel Dalio, Frehel.

results.title: Peoples of the Skeena
results.brief_description: The Getikshan and Tsimshian Indians of northern British Columbia live in two worlds. Against the mountains and forests tower the ancient totem poles; the old graveyards reveal past history; on the reserves the traditional crafts are still practised. But in the school games, in the wedding complete with white veil and white rice, and in the sawmill we see how other ways are being adopted. As climax, the film shows the action-packed rodeo at Kispiox.
